Today, roughly 500 devices and 300 hotspots were distributed to families in need, bringing the total number of laptops, tablets, and hotspots distributed in the past week alone to approximately 1,300.

Devices are handed out on a first-come, first-served basis. No appointment is needed.

Following the 2020-2021 Safety and Health-Driven Plans for Reopening approved by the Board of Education on July 23, programs will be able to allow student-athletes to return to school site athletic facilities per the established guidelines, including social distancing of 6 feet and small cohorts of athletes. Student-athletes must be cleared through their school's www.athleticclearance.com, have a valid physical, and have signed the Return To Play Waiver before participating. Site athletic directors or coaches will be contacting families in their programs with specific start dates, times, and locations in the next week as preparations are finalized. Participants will need to abide by all safety protocols as spelled out in their sport's return policy.

Emergency preparedness and planning are important for families to consider year-round. While the hope is that these emergency plans will not be necessary, having them established can help mitigate anxiety and stress during a crisis. In addition to having family plans in the event an earthquake, wildfire, or other natural disaster strikes, families are now encouraged to create plans in case they are impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.

La preparación y planificación para emergencias son importantes para que las familias las consideren durante todo el año. Mientras la esperanza es que estos planes de emergencia no sean necesarios, tenerlos establecidos puede ayudar a mitigar la ansiedad y el estrés durante una crisis. Además de tener planes familiares en caso de terremoto, incendios u otros desastres naturales, ahora se alienta a las familias a crear planes en caso de que están impactados por la pandemia de COVID-19.

https://www.orangeusd.org/about-us/news/release-article/~board/2020/post/family-pandemic-planning

Villa Park High School Track & Field Project Update:
The Board of Education last night approved an emergency resolution to ratify the decision to hire Signal Restoration Services to begin remediation work at the Villa Park High School track and athletic field.

Signal Restoration Services is working to abate abandoned buried transite (asbestos containing pipe) in an area of the new track and field space where an outside contractor had been performing excavation for State mandated Americans with Disability Act (ADA) work. The California Department of Education has made the 2019 School Dashboard available to the public, and we are proud to share that we have seen improvements in all areas. 🎉🎉🎉

The Dashboard is a key component of California’s five-year overhaul of the state’s school accountability system. It displays statewide data based on current year data (how each school or district performed) and prior year data (how much they have improved or declined from one year to the next). School and district performance levels are indicated by color, with red the lowest and blue the highest. The Dashboard also breaks down information by student group (low-income, English learner, foster youth, etc.) to help pinpoint and address achievement gaps.

Visit caschooldashboard.org or download the free mobile app at www.cde.ca.gov/re/mo/cadashboard.asp

How cute are these little "campers"?!? 😍

Our Child Development Center Preschool hosts Camp Read-a-Lot every year to highlight the importance of family involvement and the positive impact that reading and singing make in a child's life.

The event starts with families pretending that they are near a campfire. Next, the families and children go to their "forest" classrooms for story or activity time, before returning to the "campfire" to sing, and enjoy hot chocolate and s’mores. It’s a great one-hour event that is a big success each year and helps give even our smallest scholars the #OrangeUnifiedEDGE🍊
